Situation1: The partner seems mildly stressed after a routine workday.
Expectation2: Maintain client confidentiality and ethical standards
Situation2: An internal assistant unfamiliar with the matter requests access to sensitive client files for convenience.
Story: I walked through the door, briefcase in hand, and saw Alex slumped on the couch, rubbing his temples. He looked up and tried to smile, but I could tell something was off. As his girlfriend, I wanted to sit beside him, listen, and offer comfort—he always said my presence helped him unwind after a tough day. But my phone buzzed with a message from the office: the new assistant needed access to files from my latest case, files I knew were strictly confidential. As a lawyer, I was expected to uphold the highest ethical standards, never bending the rules, even for convenience. I could feel Alex’s eyes on me, waiting for me to put my phone down and be present, but my mind raced with the dilemma at work. I wanted to be the supportive partner he needed, but I also couldn’t ignore the professional responsibility tugging at me. My heart pounded as I stood in the hallway, torn between the warmth of the living room and the cold logic of my profession, unsure which demand to answer first.
